metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of ground truth measurements synchronizing with airborne PLMR mission in the Yingke oasis and Huazhaizi desert steppe on July 7, 2012
metadata.description:
On July 7, 2012, airborne ground synchronous observation was carried out in plmr quadrats of Yingke oasis and huazhaizi desert. Plmr (polarimetric L-band multibeam radiometer) is a dual polarized (H / V) L-band microwave radiometer, with a center frequency of 1.413 GHz, a bandwidth of 24 MHz, a resolution of 1 km (relative altitude of 3 km), six beam simultaneous observations, an incidence angle of ± 7 °, ± 21.5 °, ± 38.5 °, and a sensitivity of < 1K. The flight mainly covers the middle reaches of the artificial oasis eco hydrological experimental area. The local synchronous data set can provide the basic ground data set for the development and verification of passive microwave remote sensing soil moisture inversion algorithm.            
Quadrat and sampling strategy:            
The observation area is located in the transition zone between the southern edge of Zhangye Oasis and anyangtan desert, on the west side of Zhangye Daman highway, and across the trunk canal of Longqu in the north and the south, which is divided into two parts. In the southwest, there is a 1 km × 1 km desert quadrat. Because the desert is relatively homogeneous, here 1 The soil moisture of 5 points (1 point and center point around each side, and several more points can be measured during walking along the road in the actual measurement process) is collected in KM quadrat. The four corner points are 600 m apart from each other except the diagonal direction. The southwest corner point is huazhaizi desert station, which is convenient to compare with the data of meteorological station. On the northeast side, a large sample with an area of 1.6km × 1.6km was selected to carry out synchronous observation on the underlying surface of oasis. The selection of quadrat is mainly based on the consideration of the representativeness of surface coverage, avoiding residential buildings and greenhouses as much as possible, crossing oasis farmland and some deserts in the south, accessibility, and observation (road consumption) time, so as to obtain the comparison of brightness and temperature with plmr observation.            
Considering the resolution of plmr observation, 11 splines (east-west distribution) were collected at the interval of 160 m in the east-west direction. Each line has 21 points (north-south direction) at the interval of 80 M. four hydraprobe data acquisition systems (HDAS, reference 2) were used for simultaneous measurement.            Measurement content:            
About 230 points on the quadrat were obtained, each point was observed twice, that is to say, two times were observed at each sampling point, one time was inside the film (marked as a in the data record) and one time was outside the film (marked as B in the data record). As the HDAS system uses pogo portable soil sensor, the soil temperature, soil moisture (volume moisture content), loss tangent, soil conductivity, real part and virtual part of soil complex dielectric are observed. Vegetation parameter observation was carried out in some representative soil water sampling points, and the measurement of plant height and biomass (vegetation water content) was completed.            
Data:            
This data set includes two parts: soil moisture observation and vegetation observation. The former saves the data format as a vector file, the spatial location is the location of each sampling point (WGS84 + UTM 47N), and the measurement information of soil moisture is recorded in the attribute file; the vegetation sampling information is recorded in the excel table.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Verification.Question: Does the data collection method for soil moisture involve the use of Hydraprobe Data Acquisition System (HDAS) with POGO portable soil sensors?
Are the data from the multiscale dataset freely available at repositories like figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre?

Disjunctive.Question: Is the more effective data collection method for soil moisture in an oasis-desert system the use of Hydraprobe Data Acquisition System, manual point sampling, or remote sensing technologies?
Which poses a greater challenge in the field of eco-hydrological observation: the availability of multiscale observations, the calibration of sensors, or the processing of large datasets?

Concept Completion.Question: Where are the primary observation areas located for data collection in the eco-hydrological studies of the 黑河流域中游盈科绿洲与花寨子荒漠?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to observe soil moisture and vegetation dynamics in an oasis-desert ecosystem?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used involved synchronical ground measurements using the Hydraprobe Data Acquisition System to measure soil moisture, soil temperature, and other soil properties, along with vegetation parameter observations including plant height and biomass at representative soil moisture sampling points.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when collecting multiscale eco-hydrological data in heterogeneous surfaces?
Example.Answer: A challenge faced is the poor availability of multiscale observations, which hinders progress in understanding eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that includes multiscale observations for studying eco-hydrological processes in a desert oasis area?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset is the multiscale dataset obtained from the HiWATER experiment, which includes data from eddy covariance towers, meteorological stations, L-band microwave radiometer, and ground measurements of vegetation dynamics, all quality controlled through sensor calibration and data processing.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the specific features of the PLMR instrument used in remote sensing for eco-hydrological studies?
Feature Specification.Answer: dual-polarization (H/V), L-band microwave radiometer, central frequency of 1.413 GHz, bandwidth of 24 MHz, resolution of 1 km at a flight altitude of 3 km, six beams with incidence angles of ±7º, ±21.5º, ±38.5º, sensitivity of less than 1K

Feature Specification.Question: Which characteristics of ground sampling strategies are crucial for synchronizing with airborne remote sensing in eco-hydrological research?
Feature Specification.Answer: surface cover representativeness, avoid residential areas, ensure accessibility, minimize observational time, 160 m east-west intervals, 80 m north-south intervals

Quantification.Question: How many sampling points were used to collect soil moisture data in the oasis and desert areas?
How many different beam angles are utilized by the PLMR instrument during observation?
What is the resolution of the PLMR instrument when observing from an altitude of 3 km?

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'ground synchronous observation' in the context of remote sensing experiments?
Definition.Answer: Ground synchronous observation refers to the simultaneous collection of data from ground-based measurements and airborne or satellite remote sensing instruments. This method aims to provide a basis for validating and developing algorithms for remote sensing data interpretation, such as soil moisture retrieval in the context of the PLMR observations.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways might the spatial arrangement of sampling points affect the accuracy and representativeness of soil moisture data collected in eco-hydrological studies?
Interpretation.Answer: The spatial arrangement of sampling points, such as the 600 m interval between corner points and denser sampling in certain areas, can significantly influence the representativeness of the data. Properly distributed sampling points allow for a comprehensive capture of soil moisture variability, while an inadequate layout may lead to biased or incomplete representation of the area's hydrological characteristics.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors have led to the development of multiscale observation techniques in eco-hydrological research?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The development of multiscale observation techniques in eco-hydrological research is driven by the need to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces. The poor availability of multiscale observations has hindered progress in the field, prompting initiatives like HiWATER to implement instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain comprehensive data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of employing a hierarchically nested scale approach in data collection for eco-hydrological processes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing a hierarchically nested scale approach allows for capturing multi-scale and multidisciplinary data, which is crucial for understanding eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces. This approach can address the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations by providing comprehensive data from various instruments like eddy covariance towers, LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, and L-band microwave radiometers.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes can arise from focusing data collection efforts on both oasis and desert systems in an eco-hydrological study?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Focusing data collection on both oasis and desert systems allows for a comprehensive understanding of oasis-desert interactions and eco-hydrological processes. This approach can reveal how different landscapes, such as sandy deserts, desert pavement, and wetlands, interact with oasis environments, which is critical for developing accurate models and algorithms for soil moisture and other eco-hydrological parameters.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the goals of establishing a sensor network with hierarchical scales in the context of oasis-desert interactions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal of establishing a sensor network with hierarchical scales is to investigate eco-hydrological processes across different landscapes, such as oasis-desert interactions. This network allows researchers to capture data at multiple scales, enabling a detailed analysis of how different surfaces interact and affect hydrological cycles, which is essential for understanding and managing water resources in such complex environments.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are implemented to ensure the accuracy of soil moisture data collected using the Hydraprobe Data Acquisition System in the eco-hydrological experiments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The Hydraprobe Data Acquisition System uses POGO portable soil sensors to measure soil temperature, soil moisture, loss tangent, soil conductivity, and soil permittivity. The sampling strategy involves collecting data from approximately 230 points with each point having two observations to reduce errors. This includes both inside and outside the film in mulched maize plots, labeled as 'a' and 'b' respectively, to ensure comprehensive data collection. This approach is designed to provide accurate soil moisture data necessary for validating remote sensing soil moisture retrieval algorithms.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are ground measurements synchronized with airborne observations to facilitate the comparison with PLMR data in the oasis-desert eco-hydrological experiments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Ground measurements are synchronized with airborne observations by dividing the area into grid samples and systematically collecting data. In the described experiments, a grid pattern with 11 east-west lines spaced 160 meters apart and 21 sampling points at 80-meter intervals was used. This extensive sampling provides a dense data set that corresponds to the spatial resolution of the PLMR observations, allowing for effective comparison and validation of brightness temperature data obtained from the airborne L-band microwave radiometer.

Enablement.Question: What are the technological components that enable the collection of multiscale eco-hydrological data in the HiWATER experiment?
Enablement.Answer: The HiWATER experiment utilizes a variety of technological components to collect multiscale eco-hydrological data, including a flux observation matrix consisting of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations. It also uses an eco-hydrological sensor network for soil moisture and leaf area index, hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing through LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer, along with synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes.

Enablement.Question: How do the data collection methods in the HiWATER experiment address the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations?
Enablement.Answer: The HiWATER experiment addresses the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations by implementing several intensive observation periods and continuous hydrometeorological observations. Instruments are arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes, including the use of a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction, the construction of a superstation within the oasis, and the installation of multiple EC towers and automatic meteorological stations in different landscapes surrounding the oasis.

Expectation.Question: Why might obtaining multiscale observations in eco-hydrological experiments be challenging, and how can a dataset address these challenges?
Expectation.Answer: Progress in upscaling eco-hydrological processes is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. A multiscale dataset obtained from HiWATER addresses these challenges by utilizing a flux observation matrix, eco-hydrological sensor networks, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing, thereby providing comprehensive data across nested scales.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected outcomes of implementing hierarchically nested scales in data collection for an oasis-desert system?
Expectation.Answer: The expected outcomes include capturing multiscale eco-hydrological processes and investigating oasis-desert interactions effectively. By arranging instruments in hierarchically nested scales, comprehensive data can be collected to improve understanding and modeling of these complex processes.

Expectation.Question: Why might the synchronization of airborne and ground-based observations be critical in developing eco-hydrological datasets?
Expectation.Answer: Synchronization of airborne and ground-based observations ensures that data from different sources, such as L-band microwave radiometers and ground sensors, can be compared and validated, thus enhancing the accuracy and reliability of eco-hydrological datasets and supporting the development of soil moisture retrieval algorithms.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using a multiscale observation system to capture eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of a multiscale observation system is highly effective in capturing eco-hydrological processes in heterogeneous landscapes, as it incorporates various instruments like eddy covariance towers and L-band microwave radiometers to gather comprehensive data across multiple scales. This approach allows for detailed observation and analysis, which is essential for addressing challenges related to limited multiscale data availability.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in ensuring data quality and reliability when conducting intensive airborne remote sensing missions?
Judgmental.Answer: Potential challenges include maintaining the calibration and accuracy of instruments such as LiDAR and imaging spectrometers, as well as processing large volumes of data collected. Ensuring synchrony between ground measurements and airborne data is crucial for data reliability, which requires meticulous planning and execution of data collection and processing strategies.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways can soil moisture datasets be expanded or refined to improve the accuracy of eco-hydrological models?
Judgmental.Answer: Soil moisture datasets can be expanded and refined by increasing the density of sampling points and incorporating more diverse landscape features. Implementing advanced sensors and adopting a hierarchical sampling strategy can also enhance the dataset's spatial and temporal resolution, thus improving the accuracy of eco-hydrological models in representing soil moisture dynamics.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how eco-hydrological processes can be effectively captured across different scales in a heterogeneous surface.
Assertion.Answer: The HiWATER experiment addresses this challenge by using instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, such as eddy covariance towers and automated meteorological stations, to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data. This includes a sparse network to investigate oasis-desert interactions and using various remote sensing technologies.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how the collected data is quality controlled and processed for eco-hydrological research.
Assertion.Answer: Data collected during the HiWATER experiment are quality controlled through careful sensor calibration, data collection, and processing. The datasets, which include various remote sensing and ground measurements, are then carefully processed and made available through platforms like figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify the main challenges associated with collecting multiscale observations in eco-hydrological studies, and suggest potential improvements.
Request/Directive.Answer: The main challenge is the poor availability of multiscale observations. Improvements can include expanding the spatial and temporal resolution of the observation network, enhancing sensor technology, and integrating various data collection methods to ensure comprehensive coverage of eco-hydrological processes.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential strategies for expanding datasets related to soil moisture and vegetation dynamics in heterogeneous landscapes.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential strategies for expanding datasets include increasing the density and distribution of soil moisture and vegetation sampling points, employing advanced remote sensing technologies like hyperspectral imaging and L-band radiometry, and enhancing data quality through rigorous calibration and validation processes.
